represents a useful element in society. His severest
critics on the campus concede that his courage in
facing difficult social and economic problems is a
distinct asset' to the forces of "reform in all things."
He has begun one thing which we would like to
see finished, namely, his grilling of Governor Ritchie.
Last week he went down to Annapolis, with impeachment in his eye, to heavily score the Governor for his
attitude in regards to the Armwood affair. Specific
points of censure were advanced by Dr. Mitchell and
his party, but Mr. Ritchie carefully evaded all the
pointed issues and replied with a statement which
said nothing.
Practical difficulties in getting the Governor to
answer present themselves. When a man is living in
a political atmosphere he learns to give indirect replies
to all questions, because it does not do to show your
hand any more than you have to. And furthermore,
the Governor found himself in a position which no
man would relish—there simply was no explanation
which would have satisfied the men who were quizzing
him. All the weight of circumstantial evidence was
against him and he found himself in an unenviable
hole.
There may be nothing significant left to say, in
the face of these considerations. But we cannot believe that a man of Dr. Mitchell's type would be put
off with such generalizations as that "all efforts will
be made to find the lynchers." Somehow, it seems as
if the guardian of the public safety of the people of
Maryland would have more to say When there's
such a gross miscarriage of law enforcement as occurred in Princess Anne.

Some interesting facts of snake
lore are brought to mind by the lecture delivered Thursday by Dr.
Howard A. Kelly, one of the country's most prominent authorities on
matters reptile. Perhaps the most
notable of these concerns the snakecharmers, those persons who have
become famous through their supposedly supernatural powers over
snakes, and who, by these same
powers, pretend to charm them.
These "charmers" of Dr. Kelly's
subjects who have come here from
foreign lands and tried their art in
United States zoos and serpentaria
have always failed, despite all their
wheezing and whining. Not so at

home; there—be it Egypt or India
—the snakes always perform so
adeptly that the snake charmers'
fame has spread far and wide, and
the exhibit of such a "charmer"
never ceases to thrill travelers.
This standard part of Oriental
entertainment for the Occidental
visitor is sometimes impressive,
sometimes filthy, always interesting.
In these entertainments, all travelers
who pay hear a fat and sleek native
gentleman mumble and whistle and
beat a tambour. Then a cobra, no
pretty worm of Maryland, creeps
out of nowhere at his feet. It raises
its head and a length of body clear
of the ground. Then, while the
Iakir puffs his cheeks in hissing

represents a useful element in society. His severest
critics on the campus concede that his courage in
facing difficult social and economic problems is a
distinct asset' to the forces of "reform in all things."
He has begun one thing which we would like to
see finished, namely, his grilling of Governor Ritchie.
Last week he went down to Annapolis, with impeachment in his eye, to heavily score the Governor for his
attitude in regards to the Armwood affair. Specific
points of censure were advanced by Dr. Mitchell and
his party, but Mr. Ritchie carefully evaded all the
pointed issues and replied with a statement which
said nothing.
Practical difficulties in getting the Governor to
answer present themselves. When a man is living in
a political atmosphere he learns to give indirect replies
to all questions, because it does not do to show your
hand any more than you have to. And furthermore,
the Governor found himself in a position which no
man would relish—there simply was no explanation
which would have satisfied the men who were quizzing
him. All the weight of circumstantial evidence was
against him and he found himself in an unenviable
hole.
There may be nothing significant left to say, in
the face of these considerations. But we cannot believe that a man of Dr. Mitchell's type would be put
off with such generalizations as that "all efforts will
be made to find the lynchers." Somehow, it seems as
if the guardian of the public safety of the people of
Maryland would have more to say When there's
such a gross miscarriage of law enforcement as occurred in Princess Anne.

Talent Abroad
Some interesting facts of snake
lore are brought to mind by the lecture delivered Thursday by Dr.
Howard A. Kelly, one of the country's most prominent authorities on
matters reptile. Perhaps the most
notable of these concerns the snakecharmers, those persons who have
become famous through their supposedly supernatural powers over
snakes, and who, by these same
powers, pretend to charm them.
These "charmers" of Dr. Kelly's
subjects who have come here from
foreign lands and tried their art in
United States zoos and serpentaria
have always failed, despite all their
wheezing and whining. Not so at

home; there—be it Egypt or India
—the snakes always perform so
adeptly that the snake charmers'
fame has spread far and wide, and
the exhibit of such a "charmer"
never ceases to thrill travelers.
This standard part of Oriental
entertainment for the Occidental
visitor is sometimes impressive,
sometimes filthy, always interesting.
In these entertainments, all travelers
who pay hear a fat and sleek native
gentleman mumble and whistle and
beat a tambour. Then a cobra, no
pretty worm of Maryland, creeps
out of nowhere at his feet. It raises
its head and a length of body clear
of the ground. Then, while the
Iakir puffs his cheeks in hissing
